questions.text: Are you aware of what metadata is?

options.text: Yes, I understand what metadata is.
No, I’m not familiar with it.

questions.explanation: As the number of shared photos increase, metadata is also being increasingly shared; data that is attached to various forms of content (including photos or images) that can unintentionally reveal individuals’ personal information: when a photo was taken (date and time), where it was taken (which can reveal a pattern), and may even lead to identity theft from hackers or bad entities. It is wise to remove metadata before sharing files publicly.

questions.text: Do you typically remove metadata from your photos before sharing them online?

options.text: Yes, I always remove metadata.
Sometimes, but not always.
No, I never remove metadata.

questions.explanation: As the number of shared photos increase, metadata is also being increasingly shared; data that is attached to various forms of content (including photos or images) that can unintentionally reveal individuals’ personal information: when a photo was taken (date and time), where it was taken (which can reveal a pattern), and may even lead to identity theft from hackers or bad entities. It is wise to remove metadata before sharing files publicly.

questions.text: Do you believe that using incognito mode, privacy mode, VPN or TOR browser will keep you completely secure?

options.text: Yes, I believe that it keeps me completely secure.
No, I don’t believe that it keeps me completely secure.

questions.explanation: Individuals may have a misconception about various privacy tools that are usable in today’s society, which places them at a disadvantage when it comes to security and privacy. It is important to realize that limitations arise with what is protected from Tor Browser, VPNs, and Private Browsing: Private Browsing is wonderful because it protects against local browsing history and cookie storage but it isn't the case outside of your browser; especially since websites or your ISP can still track or see your activity. It also doesn’t provide protection from malware. VPNs or Virtual Private Networks is a tool that can encrypt your internet traffic and mask your IP address which is what websites are able to see. However, it is important to realize that VPNs don't inherently give full anonymity, especially because ISPs are still able to see your VPN connection but not the specific activity. Tor Browser is a browser that anonymizes a user’s web traffic by going through different ‘relays’ and is also great at masking your IP address, but it does not actually prevent all forms of tracking; especially when logging into an account nor does it provide protections outside the browser.

questions.text: When creating a new password, which option best describes your approach?

options.text: I use easy-to-remember passwords (e.g., names, dates).
I use a mix of letters, numbers, and symbols.
I use a password manager to generate strong, unique passwords.

questions.explanation: Weak passwords, such as easily guessed ones, put users at a high risk of account compromise. Using a mix of letters, numbers, and symbols offers moderate protection, but using a password manager to generate unique and strong passwords provides the highest level of security by eliminating repetition and the risk of forgetting complex passwords.

questions.text: Have you reviewed and updated your privacy settings on social media accounts?

options.text: Never.
Yes, I set my privacy options once when creating my account.
Regularly, at least once every few months.

questions.explanation: Regularly updating your privacy settings reduces the risk of exposing personal information to strangers or malicious entities. Notifications and updates from platforms can remind you to check and adjust your privacy settings to ensure better protection of your data

questions.text: Are you aware of your social media visibility settings (e.g., public, friends only, private)?

options.text: Yes, I’ve configured my settings intentionally.
No, I haven’t checked or adjusted my visibility settings.

questions.explanation: Public visibility can expose your posts and personal information to anyone, increasing the risk of identity theft or unwanted attention.

questions.text: Do you regularly review the apps connected to your social media accounts (e.g., third-party apps using Facebook or Google login)?

options.text: Yes, I review and remove unnecessary apps.
No, I haven’t checked recently.

questions.explanation: Connected third-party apps can access your personal data and may pose privacy risks. Regularly reviewing and removing unnecessary apps ensures that only trusted services have access to your information, minimizing the chances of misuse.

questions.text: How would you respond if an app that you use frequently suddenly asks for new permissions (e.g., access to microphone or location)?

options.text: Check the app’s permissions and reviews to investigate.
Grant the permission if it seems necessary.
I don’t look into it and grant the permission.
Ignore the change and continue using the app.

questions.explanation: Granting unnecessary app permissions, such as access to your location or microphone, may expose sensitive information. Regularly reviewing app permissions ensures that apps only access what is necessary for functionality, minimizing privacy risks.

questions.text: Do you click on ‘Remember Me’ or ‘Stay Signed In’ on public/shared computers?

options.text: Yes, always.
Sometimes, if I trust the location or device.
No, I avoid using this feature on shared devices.

questions.explanation: Enabling or using the 'Remember Me' or 'Stay Signed In' on a public or shared computer (e.g., a desktop at home or a public computer at a library) is an unwise idea because it poses significant security and privacy risks since it stores your credentials on the computer which will allow others to automatically log into your account during subsequent visits without the usage of a password; enabling or potentially leading to a compromised account.

questions.text: Do you believe that using Incognito Mode, Privacy Mode, or VPNs keeps you completely secure online?

options.text: Yes, I believe they offer complete protection.
No, I understand they offer some privacy but do not guarantee full security.

questions.explanation: Incognito mode only prevents local browsing history storage. VPNs and TOR help mask your location but do not protect against all threats.

questions.text: When a website asks for permissions (e.g., location, camera, notifications), what do you usually do?

options.text: I accept all permissions without checking.
I only grant permissions if they seem necessary.
I deny all permissions unless I understand why they’re needed.

questions.explanation: Granting unnecessary permissions, such as access to your location or camera, may expose sensitive information. Regularly reviewing website permissions ensures that websites only access what is necessary for functionality, minimizing privacy risks.

questions.text: When a service offers an option to opt out of data collection, what do you usually do?

options.text: I ignore it and proceed without opting out.
I check and opt out if possible.

questions.explanation: Opting out of data collection is a wise idea because it ensures that you are not inadvertently collecting data that may be used for tracking or targeted advertising. It also helps protect your privacy and personal information by reducing the amount of data that is collected and processed by the service.

questions.text: Do you regularly update your phone’s operating system to the latest version?

options.text: Yes, I update it as soon as updates are available.
No, I delay updates or ignore them.

questions.explanation: Updating your phone’s Operating System (OS) is a huge recommendation from many cybersecurity researchers and experts since there are constantly new security flaws, issues, and bugs discovered that can be exploited by attackers to steal one’s personal information or take control of the device; updating mitigates these issues and ensures a constant safeguard of your security and privacy.

questions.text: Can you remotely lock or erase your phone if it’s lost or stolen?

options.text: Yes, I’ve set up this feature.
No, I haven’t enabled this feature.

questions.explanation: Being able to remotely lock or erase your phone if it is lost or stolen is a wise idea because it helps protect your personal data or information since they are digitally stored on your device: emails, contacts, and messages and also including things like photos or videos and banking details. If it falls into the wrong hands, taking these necessary steps prevents individuals from using it to their advantage.

questions.text: Do you always keep your Wi-Fi and Bluetooth turned on, even when not in use?

options.text: Yes, I leave them on for convenience.
No, I turn them off when not needed.

questions.explanation: Bluetooth connectivity and Bluetooth-enabled devices is a convenient and popular form of wireless communication that can connect to a multitude of devices: laptops, smartphones, printers, and desktops which don’t require a cable to function. However, it is important to realize the security threats that can arise if this setting is enabled on your device. Security intruders are constantly discovering new and more complex ways to intercept the transmission of data signals. Bluetooth has been found to be ranked fourth in terms of the top security concerns. Some concerns include: Virus Infection, BlueBugging, and BluePrinting.

questions.text: Are you aware of the permissions requested by the apps on your phone (e.g., location, microphone, contacts)?

options.text: Yes, I regularly check and manage app permissions.
No, I usually accept all permissions without checking.

questions.explanation: Granting unnecessary app permissions, such as access to your location or microphone, may expose sensitive information. Regularly reviewing app permissions ensures that apps only access what is necessary for functionality, minimizing privacy risks.

questions.text: What do you usually do when you see a security warning?

options.text: Read it fully and follow the advice.
Skim it and follow the advice if it seems serious.
Ignore it and proceed.
Close it without reading.

questions.explanation: Security warnings are designed to alert users to potential threats. Ignoring them increases vulnerability to malware, phishing, and data theft. Reading and following these warnings helps prevent avoidable risks

questions.text: If you encounter a security warning that you don’t fully understand or grasp, what would you do?

options.text: Ignore the warning and continue using the website or app, trusting that everything is likely fine.
Google it.
Check website FAQ or warning page if available.

questions.explanation: Ignoring security warnings is a risky practice because it can lead to potential risks such as malware infections, phishing attacks, and data theft. It is recommended to read and follow the security warnings fully and understand the potential risks before proceeding with any action.

questions.text: Which method do you typically rely on for verifying your identity during account recovery?

options.text: Using common security questions (e.g., 'What’s your mother’s maiden name?')
Receiving a code via SMS or phone call
Verifying through email link sent to your inbox
Using two-factor authentication (2FA) through a secure app (e.g., Authenticator app or biometric verification)

questions.explanation: The use of two-factor authentication (2FA) provides the most secure identity verification method. Common security questions or SMS-based recovery are less secure due to risks like SIM swapping or social engineering

questions.text: Do you use the same password for multiple accounts?

options.text: Yes, for most accounts.
Yes, but only for less important accounts.
No, I use unique passwords for each account.

questions.explanation: Using the same password across multiple accounts increases the risk of a domino effect in case one account is compromised. Unique passwords ensure that a single breach doesn’t expose all your accounts
